23993734.review:
It's been a long time since I've done an actual review, but I just couldn't pass up the opportunity to gush about this game. This game right here, 'Khimera: Destroy All Monster Girls' is slowly becoming one of my personal favorites. I only found out about it a couple days ago, and it's practically all I've been playing since.

The story's that there's this island called Morgana, inhabited mainly by monster girls. These pirate monster girls come to the island and steal all of it's money. You play as this demon girl created by a mad scientist (he's not really) and you've been chosen to get back the island's fortune from the pirates with your new golem arm.

This is an action platformer which bears a striking resemblance in playstyle to Megaman, specifically the Megaman X games. You got your dashs, dash jumps, air dashs, shootin'... Well, maybe not so that. As well as dashing, you also have a variety of close-ranged melee attacks to pick off your enemies. From the world map you select stages to go to find and collect as much money as you can and fight a boss at the end. 

Similar to Megaman, as you defeat these bosses, you'll gain their powers, making the next stages easier. Unlike Megaman, all these powers you get are passive upgrades to your already powerful golem arm cannon. As a result, there are no real 'weaknesses' to any of the stage's obstacles and or bosses, meaning you can go through each stage without feeling like you're missing anything you need to win.

The controls are tight, simple, and easy to get into. The buttons are also fully customizable to fit your needs for keyboard and controller. The graphics are simplistic and retro, obviously trying to capture the aspect of the good ol' 16-bit era. The music is very catchy, and the songs are fitting for their location. It's kind of a side thing, but the game has a very cutesy charm to it. Through the writing and characters, it's quite appealing to that demographic for old video game fans and fans of monster girls. I can't say I don't understand that demographic. *wink* Don't be fooled by it's looks though, this game is quite challenging. It has that happy-go-lucky feel when you're doing good, and the crushing feeling of defeat when you die and lose that 100% treasure collection.

The game is however, very short. You can beat it in little under 30 minutes if you're not going for any secrets or 100% completion. It does have that replay value of finding all the secrets, doing everything, and trying to get the fastest times on all stages. If not, you may not find this an appealing purchase. But wait...The game is completely FREE TO PLAY! (Unless you buy DLC that is)

In conclusion, I highly recommend you play this game. Even if action games aren't your forte, you should definitely give this one a go. And that about does it, I give it 10/10, pick it up from your local gamestop, and, uh, yeah.

Oh yeah, when you do play it, contact me at [REDACTED] and tell me which monster you'd date, marry, and kill. 
I'd personally date the pizza slime girl (first time would be last ;^) ) marry the maid spider girl, and I'd probably kill the Chibeara, because that was kind of an annoying boss.  Thanks for reading!

Khimera: Destory All Monster Girls is one of the best platformers I've played this year. Plus, it's free! It's a really great game, with lots of content; it took me about 6 hours to find all the collectibles and an additional 3 to earn A ranks/not die/finish in berserk mode. It's a lot of fun, and easy to compare to Shovel Knight in many ways; most of Chelshia's moves resemble Shovel Knight's, and even some of the level design/mechanics are similar. However, Khimera has a charm all its own, with lots of cute characters, writing, music, and artwork. I would have easily recommended this even if it had cost $10, but as a free game all I can say is "GET IT NOW, YOU CRAZY PERSON." I played the whole game on an Xbox One controller and it controlled perfectly.

I've still easily got another couple hours in this doing the speedruns for the last 2 achievements I have left to go, and I'll revisit it more if future patches bring more content like some of the past ones have done.

I give it a 9/10, and if you let the free factor count, then I'd give it a 10/10 really.

P.S. Anchovy is best monster waifu, fight me.

UPDATE:

The game had a free Halloween(ish) themed update that adds another level, enemy types, codex entries, and boss. Also candy because it's [not] Halloween. It's a good update, adding a little epilogue to an already cute game. It even adds 3 more achievements to earn! A real class act, this game is.

23466426.review:
It's pretty much Shovel Night meets Monster Musume(except with less lewdness), but cheeper.

For what it is, it works quite well and has some nice little replay value in the ranking system, controls work pretty good. You aren't likely to walk off ledges or do something stupid too easy(except on the airship stage). And that said, the controls are very simple and easy to get a hold of, especially the game's incredibly important dash attack. It's just a simply dash like in any other game(with an air version too), but it'll always be there when speed running or you need to jump large gaps. It's chock full of oddball humor, especially durring boss encounters, which include things like a pizza slime, that always manages to be endearing or at least chickle inducing.

The only negative I'd have to say is level design. It's effective "big brother game" Shovel Knight, was always about making levels where if you messed up it was your fault entirely(some exceptions). The levels were designed percise and expertly. In Khimera, they are less so. They are a few jerkish designs for some levels(airship in particular) that just clearly shouldn't have been a good idea in hindsight. Like, areas where a mistake will cost you your life, and not by pits. They are plenty of good scenes, but occasionaly some stupid bits slip in and put a plug on the fun for a while.

In any event, this is certainly a game that could have been sold for 5 - 10 aproximate USD but chose to be a freebie. So that's pretty nice of the game makers.

I don't want to cheapen the entire game to just a clone because it does have its own unique charms and highlights. The music and replay value is also high. I hadn't intended to play through it in a single session, but it was too good to put down.

23345744.review: First of all, I love monstergirls. So I was happy to find out this game exists, and happier to find out it's both free and fun. The game is clearly and proudly based off the megaman platform games. Like the megaman games, you make your way through themed stages, each with thier own set of enemies and hazrds that get harder the further you get into the stage before you face a boss and defeat them for a new power like having a double jump, or a charge shot. The game itself is also much more forgiving then  most old school platformers. The stages themselves can be tricky, the pirate ship ones having lots of traps that need good timing to avoid. But the bosses are all easy. They leave themselves open for long periods which means rushing in and smashing them in the face is the way to go. The only boss to put up a challenge is the last stage of the final boss, and that's more due to the moving platfroms and the spikes you have to deal with.  The game is short, but that's to be expected when it's free.  There is stuff to do after you beat all the stages. you can find fairies and books hidden in the stages, and retry for A ranks and Deathless and Beserk runs.

23336546.review:
Khimera is a wonderful, nostalgic labor of love. It hearkens back to an era when most games were colorful and cheerful rather than gritty and grim, when games had punishing difficulty curves and when mastering a particular portion felt rewarding, when games were loaded with secrets and fed a sense of wonderment and discovery. These were the games of my childhood, and this is the niche that Khimera fits into.

Far more than a mere nod to the past, Khimera feels like a lost classic of early gaming. Its artwork, music, humor, and gameplay all work together to deliver one of the most satisfying (and for free, no less!) games I\'ve encountered in some time.

In short, if you like fun, happiness, and childlike innocence, you should download this game. Because that\'s what this game is-- distilled happiness and a  chance to recapture, at least for a couple of hours, what it felt like to be 8 years old. That\'s a magical feeling.

I already can\'t wait for the sequel.

Another day looking for free games with achievements, another gem discovered. This game was made with GameMaker, but don't be fooled, it's a good experience.

Play as Chelshia, a chimera who was created to accomplish household chores, but was modified at the last minute to stop some evil-doers with her "Rock Arm". Wait.....this sounds familiar........ You'll be facing off against monster girl pirates who have stolen from the town of good monster girls and....wait, this IS familiar!!

That's right, this game is essentially a fusion of Rockman (Megaman) and Shantae...only with a focus on monster girls! Face off against a naga, a harpy, a mermaid, a mimic (chest), a pizza slime (like...a slimegirl made of pizza) and a dridder (spider girl)!!!

PROS:
+ Retro gameplay
+ Free
+ Achievements
+ Great humor
+ Challenging start
+ Occassional lesbian humor and tsundere humor
+ Small download (51 MB)

CONS:
- Starts a bit hard, but rewards you a bit too much for collecting everything (Berserk's pros outweigh the cons)
- Feels a bit generic in the beginning (but the game grows on you)
- Dash attack can be spammed to win easilly.


If you want a free Rockman (Megaman) or Shantae, this is right up your alley. A free game you'll be surprised at for not having a price tag.

Hope we see Chelshia again in the near future!

Ok so I spent quite a bit of time with this game, so now i can honestly say that i give it an enthusiastic recommendation. If you like platformer games at all then you pretty much have to play this game since not only is it completely free, but it is also a very solid little game. 

I am not a platformer fan at all so I found the game to be a bit too difficult at first, but fortunately, with a bit of practice and some helpful tips I will get to in a second, you will eventually be left wondering why you were having so much trouble with these levels earlier.

I'm not sure what motivated me to stick with the game despite my early struggles, it could be the nice looking retro graphics, the awesome music, or the excellent and funny writing, but there was just a charm to this game that made me want to keep trying. 

You can tell alot of care went into it, definitely worth a try! I had alot of fun in the time I had with it.

Pros:
- fast and fun gameplay
- nice and unique character designs
- really great music
- lots of funny dialogue
- surprising amount of secrets and extras for a free game

Cons:
-some of the checkpoints are too far apart for my taste (I'm looking at you, oil rig!)
-at the point where you can choose the order in which you will beat the next 4 stages, the game's 2 hardest levels (Mt. Afrokoopa and oil rig) happen to be the closest to your starting position.
-a couple of the bosses can be cheesed pretty hard by your dash attack.
-the new race mode achievement, while not impossible, is a bit too unforgiving.

and finally, if you're like me when it comes to these kind of games, here's some tips I found invaluably helpful:

-dash attack is your best friend, its not only awesomely effective against most enemies but there are a ton of jumps that require you to use dash. If you are having a hard time getting the dash to work properly on your keyboard then try using W for it instead! You can dash with only 1 button by pressing W.

-If you feel you need more HP then the 4 measely hearts the game gives you then you can upgrade your life total by finding an NPC called gourmet gal who is hidden somewhere in the 4 levels after the one where you fight the snake girl. There is a guide on where she is located in each level that you can check if you want to guarantee that you won't miss her.

-try beating the sky fortress first. Not only is it one of the easier levels in the game imo, but beating it will unlock a double jump for your character that can make platforming in the rest of the game alot easier.

23060976.review:
Alright, I'll get all up in this.

[i]Khimera[/i] is a retro-style side-scrolling platform-bouncing beat-em-up, featuring the most adorable of protagonists ever.

[b]What's the story?[/b]
There's a peaceful and rich island somewhere, and it's full of monster girls. Then, pirates attack for the money. Meanwhile, a scientist had just finished building a chimera [Cheshia], when he's asked to help save the island. He gives the chimera a golem arm to beat pirates up with. Then you go beat up a lamia [she has arms, she can't be a naga].

[b]Gameplay?[/b]
You have a number of actions you can use to battle the pirates.
- Normal punch
- Strong punch
- Dash punch
- Air punch
- Ground punch

While each should fill their own role, the dash punch is highly spammable, meaning it's superior to the rest in the boss fights [or at least one boss fight].

[b]Level Design?[/b]
Some levels are just painful to try playing [Oil Rig, Airship Fortress]. Some are easier, but only slightly. If you can beat Mega Man, you may only have slight difficulties with this game. If you haven't, you're straight boned.

[b]Distractions?[/b]
You can play a weird Mario Bros./Wrecking Crew imitation called Cake Boy. There's a chef in a place with cakes, signs, sweets, doors and snakes. The goal is to score points by collecting sweets, getting the cake to the white door or blowing up enemies with bombs. Each door leads to the other door of the same color, and cracked doors break after use.

[b]So, overall?[/b]
This is a game. It exists. If it costed money, you can bet the top of your legs it'd be worth a fiver. But it doesn't.
Which lets me rate it:
9/10 [Almost perfect]

23030803.review:
[i]Revised for v.1.2: 22/05/16[/i]
Khimera is a free game, so any complaints should not deter you from trying it. Its style and personality counts for a lot, but the difficulty may not suit some players.

Pros: [list]
[*] Really nice art style with a wide range of great character designs.
[*] Amusing dialogue and an interesting plot.
[*] Really nails that 'retro' feeling throughout.
[*] A sort of mixture of Mario 3, Mega Man and Castlevania.
[*] Some good platforming [i](see below)[/i] and plenty of hidden collectables.
[*] It's free, so you risk nothing by trying it. [/list]

Neutrals: [list]
[*] Treasure pickups are your rank, and dying removes a chunk of cash. A single death will pretty much guarentee no A-rank, and almost all of my ranks are C. It promotes perfectionism and punishes the smallest mistakes (though there is no 'punishment' beyond the rank itself). [/list]

Cons: [list]
[*] Insta-death platforming, where one mistimed jump will ruin your no-death run of the level and send you way back. Enemy hits stun you mid-air, too.
[*] Sparse checkpoints and health pickups are extremely rare, so be prepared to replay 5-10 minutes over and over until you get it right. On instakill, two-block-wide platforming sections with wind, this becomes incredibly frustrating.
[*] Enemies enter the space you occupy and damage you with contact. While your defence against this had improved since 1.2, it is still a major source of damage from enemies that attack you, remaining out of hit-range and stunning you from turning. This is compounded by flying, tracking enemies that are incredibly hard to hit --even pixels above your head-- if they're slightly off-center. Not only that, but it makes the dash-attack extremely risky, as it will usually result in you taking damage too. These might be fixed with enemeis being knocked back when they damage you, slightly wider range on vertical attacks, and some invunerability frames on the dash.[/list]

In summation, it's really cute and worth trying. The platforming is fun when it isn't a series of insta-death drops; the fighting is mashy and basic enemies can overcome you if you're not paying attention; and the difficulty is punishing, but levels are actually completeable now, so I can happily recommend this to everyone (but don't expect to fly through it).

22956104.review:
Alright, here we go...

It's either a very fast platformer or a very slow one. If you get hit by an enemy while it's advancing and try to hit it afterwards, doesn't work. Jump back and THEN punch. I wanted to go fast, but the game forced me to go slowly and precisely.

Some mini boss attacks are impossible to read unless you've played before, for example, the mini boss in... Pumpkin something? Can't remember. Anyway, that mini boss has an attack that goes in a straight line across the screen in an instant and you have no way of knowing if it will do that attack until it has attacked.

You WILL get hit and you WILL get salty. You either play it till the end or not.




On that note, I can still recommend it since it's still, what, version 1.1?. It's on the hard side until you learn how to play it well, which I didn't. 
There are a lot of positive things to say about this game, but I'm not a very positive person and always choose to focus on the negative instead of talking about the good things in life. 

It's not a bad game, just a very rage inducing one. Well, for me anyway. Give it a try.

22898847.review:
Out of all the free games I've played on Steam, this one certainly feels the meatiest.

Khimera: Destroy All Monster Girls is a Mega Man-style action-platformer with beat-em-up elements that pays homage to a number of established retro games. You can definitely tell there is a lot of love poured into this game, from the colorful graphics to the catchy music to the tight platforming and tough enemies. It's a little easier than most classic Mega Man games, but still a bit too difficult for my tastes. 

I really recommend this game to platforming fanatics and people who just want to look for a fairly challenging game with quite a bit of content for the price tag of nothing.

39404689.developer_response:
If you accidentally enter controls that make the game unplayable, you can either reboot the game without the controller plugged in or press F2 to revert controls to the default keyboard settings.

In the case of the D-Pad not working, if you post more details in the Khimera discussion one of us may be able to help you further but often the case is that you would need to manually assign the directions to the D-Pad in the control settings menu.

39358068.review:
It's cute, funny, great characters, and it's fun.  It's also free so if you can just try it for yourself, watch the first cutscene or play the first level, and you'll probably be sold (or not) on the game, and then decide if you want to buy the Nurse outfit DLC. (which is only a dollar anyways).  Got everything in the game (except the speedrun challenges) in 8 hours which is pretty good considering this is free.  I also love games that give bonus entries on things, and this one gives entries for every boss, enemy, and most other characters in the game if you collect the journals.

The game's pretty Megaman styled with the basic formula being going through a stage, beat the boss, and get an upgrade.  There's hidden stages too which also give power-ups for completing them, and one sub-quest in the town that gives you one more.  Some of the collectables (as well as the detonators that unlock the other stages) are pretty well hidden, but you can get an upgrade which helps look for them.  The titular Khimera also has the same backstory as Megaman (A creation made to clean the lab, that must be hastily upgraded to be combat ready and fight evil).  The biggest problem is the bosses are a bit too easy, and you can often kill them before even needing to figure out their patterns fully, but the bosses include a slime made out of Pizza, and an engineer harpie that secretly like anime which is pretty great.  You chat with these bosses all the time too, even after beating them, and they're great characters to hang around.  If anything, the hidden boss, the Chi-bear-a, is the most disappointing because you don't do anything else with it besides the boss fight and the journal entry.  At least the last boss was a bit more difficult, and the secrets can be a bit harder to find (spoilers: the last two I got were the journal in the "Cake boy" minigame that appears in a later stage, and the tent on the World map that you can walk into).

I'd easily recommend this game.  Primarily because it's free, but you can also get the Doctor's assistant DLC just to support the developers anyways.  It's only a dollar anyways (though I personally like the Magician's outfit from the Festival bonus stage better)

39296202.review:
Lo exprimí todo lo que pude (8.2 horas hasta escribir este análisis) y aun me falta por exprimirle 2 logros mas.

Lo bueno.

-Demasiado bueno para ser gratis, no me dolería pagar por este juego y por eso merece ser pagado el DLC.

-Un diseño de niveles muy muy bueno, tanto que recuerdan a Mega Man o Shovel Knight.

-Un menejo del personaje muy muy fluido y pulido, con algo de habilidad y reflejos te volveras casi indestructible
(importante a la hora de los SpeedRun)

-La musica es pegajosa a mas no poder, esta buenisima

-El arte, parece ser muy simplista pero tiene mucho encanto y carisma

-Habemus waifus (para los que les gusten las chicas monstruo)

-Una cantidad increíble de referencias, te sacaran mas de una sonrisa




Lo malo.

-El hitbox no esta muy bien cuidado, en especial a la hora de hacer el Dash/puñetazo, o rebotas, o no le pegas a el enemigo, no le pegas al enemigo y lo atrviezas por lo consiguiente te llevas daño gratuito, o simplemente no le haces nada.... cosa que te desanimara si haces SpeedRun (Berserker Mode y Race Mode).

-Los jefes son muy faciles, no representa mayor desafio (y mas si se abusa del Charge Shoot de Anchovy, pero esto es divagar)




Aun con lo malo, deberias jugar Khimera Destroy All Monster Girls?
pero por supuesto!

que haces aquí perdiendo el tiempo y escuchando voces en tu cabeza?
anda, a jugarlo.
